Caption: Fig. 1. The main PivotSlice interface: (a) Search and Operation Panel, (b) History Panel, (c) Information Panel, (d) Main Canvas, and (e) Cell Relation Panel. The user is conducting faceted exploration by sub-dividing the entire data into 3-by-4 regions and discovering relationships among different sub-datasets, using the a table of queries constructed by two sets of filters on both axes.
Fig. 2. An illustration of the visual query logic in PivotSlice.
Fig. 5. Viewing the time trend of papers using the keywords Direct Ma- nipulation or Dynamic Query from conferences InfoVis, CHI and UIST.

Fig. 3. A 2-by-2 division of the dataset with keywords Information Visual- ization, User Interface, and Visualization Technique versus conferences InfoVis, CHI and UIST, where the conference facet in the Data Filter is used for aligning the nodes.
Fig. 6. Identifying highly-cited publications with keywords of Direct Ma- nipulation and Dynamic Query as well as Information Space and World Wide Web. The “others” row and column are minimized.

Fig. 3. A 2-by-2 division of the dataset with keywords Information Visual- ization, User Interface, and Visualization Technique versus conferences InfoVis, CHI and UIST, where the conference facet in the Data Filter is used for aligning the nodes.
Fig. 8. Comparing publication trends between B. Shneiderman and S. Card by year.

Fig. 11. Adding new attributes via (a) searching on the Search and Operation Panel and (b)(c) dragging from the Information Panel.

Fig. 10. The visual encodings of a filter (with a year facet of 1990– 2010, a keyword facet of 6 attributes, and an empty author facet): (a) the default view, (b) hovering over a numerical facet, and (c) hovering over a categorical facet.

Fig. 9. Aggregated (a–c), force directed (d–f), and facet aligned (e–g) layouts of nodes in a cell (the vertical axis is the Conference facet with 3 attributes and the horizontal axis is the Year facet with range 1990–2010).
Fig. 12. User satisfaction results from the post-study questionnaire.

Table 1. Experimental tasks for evaluating PivotSlice, organized by the 10 low level components of analytic activities in information visualization proposed by Amar et al. [3], plus three high level open-ended tasks.
